review.title: Improving a Credit Scoring Model by Incorporating Bank Statement Derived Features
review.abstract: In this paper, we investigate the extent to which features derived from bank statements provided by loan applicants, and which are not declared on an application form, can enhance a credit scoring model for a New Zealand lending company. Exploring the potential of such information to improve credit scoring models in this manner has not been studied previously. We construct a baseline model based solely on the existing scoring features obtained from the loan application form, and a second baseline model based solely on the new bank statement-derived features. A combined feature model is then created by augmenting the application form features with the new bank statement derived features. Our experimental results using ROC analysis show that a combined feature model performs better than both of the two baseline models, and show that a number of the bank statement-derived features have value in improving the credit scoring model. The target data set used for modelling was highly imbalanced, and Naive Bayes was found to be the best performing model, and outperformed a number of other classifiers commonly used in credit scoring, suggesting its potential for future use on highly imbalanced data sets.

metadata.title: Improving a Credit Scoring Model by Incorporating Bank Statement Derived Features

sections.text: In this paper, we examine the extent to which features derived from borrowers "bank statements that are not declared on an application form can improve a credit rating model for a New Zealand credit institution. To date, the potential of such information to improve credit rating models has not been investigated. We construct a base model based solely on the existing rating features of the credit rating form and a second base model based solely on the new features derived from the statement. A combined feature model is then created by adding the new features of the statement to the application form. Our experimental results show that a combined feature model performs better than the two base models and that a number of the derived features of the statement have a value for improving the credit rating model.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: Credit scoring models are often used by banks and other financial institutions to assess the risk of default by applicants for loans previously determined on the basis of case studies only. Credit scoring models take a vector of attributes for a borrower and try to distinguish between commodities and commodities based on these attributes; that is, between those who are likely to be insolvent or in default on their payments and those who are. A lender in New Zealand evaluates borrowers on the basis of 11 attributes derived from an application form that is filled out online when applying for a loan. The lender had recently begun to include data from an application called Credit Sense 1 in its data warehouse, which automatically extracts bank statement data for a 90-day issuance.The bank statement data is currently used for purposes such as credit verification. The company was interested in examining the potential of this data for credit scoring purposes.

sections.heading: 6. Conclusions and Future Work
sections.text: This research has supplemented features provided by credit applicants during the application process, and this work has highlighted the potential to use account statements from applications such as Credit Sense to provide additional features to enhance credit rating. Although the account statements themselves were not sufficiently predictable, our experimental results showed that a number of statements had value in supplementing the application forms to enhance a credit model. Specifically, we found that a Naive Bayes model, which had 16 combined features in the area below the ROC curve (AUC), had a value in supplementing the application forms, had a credit model.

metadata.abstractText: In this paper, we investigate the extent to which features derived from bank statements provided by loan applicants, and which are not declared on an application form, can enhance a credit scoring model for a New Zealand lending company. Exploring the potential of such information to improve credit scoring models in this manner has not been studied previously. We construct a baseline model based solely on the existing scoring features obtained from the loan application form, and a second baseline model based solely on the new bank statement derived features. A combined feature model is then created by augmenting the application form features with the new bank statement derived features. Our experimental results show that a combined feature model performs better than both of the two baseline models, and that a number of the bank statement derived features have value in improving the credit scoring model. As is often the case in credit scoring, our target data was highly imbalanced, and Naive Bayes was found to be the best performing classifier, outperforming a number of other classifiers commonly used in credit scoring. Future experimentation with Naive Bayes on other highly imbalanced credit scoring data sets will help to confirm whether the classifier should be more commonly used in the credit scoring context.
